Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Liquid Printed Metal Nanomeshes for Transparent Conductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation (SBIR) Phase I Project is the demonstration of metal nanomeshes as a disruptive new technology. This innovation has the potential to exceed the performance of indium tin oxide, the industrial standard transparent conductor. The key features of the proposed technology are that it can be processed atmospheric pressure and low temperatures, the metal nanomeshes feature high durability, which may enable new touch screen applications, and the metal nanomeshes exhibit uniform performance over micron length scales. Opportunities are anticipated in touchscreen devices. Additional opportunities may emerge in organic light emitting diode displays, lighting and solar cells.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to develop new metal inks and metal patterning techniques to print metal nanomesh structures with high transparency and low sheet resistance. The key advantages of the new metal inks are that they decompose at low temperatures, solidify into pure metals with high conductivities, demonstrate high conductivity at sub-micron film thicknesses, bend and flex without cracking, and exhibit versatility in variety of industrial printing processes. Simulations studies will be utilized to understand how to design nanomeshes with high transmission, low sheet resistance, and low haze. New additive printing processes that pattern sub-micron features from metal inks will be developed. Metal nanomeshes are expected to exhibit high durability under bending and deformation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the work completed on our NSF grant, Liquid X has finalized the prototype stage of its metal mesh. Some of the benefits of Liquid X’s metal mesh technology over ITO include a more cost effective solution, improved processability, and enhanced nanomesh properties including very high figure of merit, increased transmission and sheet resistance which allows for increased device efficiency. Also, ITO faces geopolitical challenges complicating the supply chain and our product does not face these same challenges. These are all reasons that Liquid X’s metal mesh will outperform and begin to replace ITO as a transparent conductors.

 One may ask why chose Liquid X inks to create these metal meshes when there are competitive products on the market. The biggest difference is that  Liquid X inks are unique because they do not contain nanoparticles or flakes. This gives us numerous advantages over our competition. We are not limited by particle size or agglomeration which allows for increased processability and reduced down time of equipment. Liquid X inks are able to be put down as a thin film or narrow trace and when cured, provide high conductivity even when stretched or stressed. Another major advantage to Liquid X inks is our unique ability to adhere to any surface. This can be attributed to the unique chemical structure of our inks. When you consider all of these benefits, Liquid X has a clear competitive advantage over the other silver inks on the market.
